Situation1: The meeting is a routine catch-up that will be recorded for anyone who cannot make it.
Situation2: A passenger who booked through the app is waiting and urgently pressing for a quicker arrival.
Story: I glanced at the clock on my dashboard, my phone buzzing with a reminder: team meeting in five minutes. As a colleague, I was expected to join, share updates, and show I was part of the team—even if today’s meeting was just a routine catch-up, and they’d record it for anyone who missed it. But right now, I was behind the wheel, my other job as a taxi driver demanding my full attention. The app pinged again—a passenger, already waiting, sent another urgent message: “Please hurry, I can’t be late!” I felt the pressure mounting. If I joined the meeting, I’d have to pull over, making my passenger wait even longer, risking a bad review and possibly losing future fares. But if I skipped the meeting, I’d miss out on team discussions and might seem disengaged to my colleagues. My hands tightened on the steering wheel, my mind racing between the expectations of being a reliable teammate and a professional driver, both pulling me in opposite directions.
